newsitem.title: USA: G7 tells Bosnians: make peace or lose aid.
newsitem.headline: G7 tells Bosnians: make peace or lose aid.

text.p: Leaders of the world's big industrial powers demanded in a draft statement on Saturday that Balkan leaders do more to protect peace in Bosnia or face a cut-off in international aid.

In a statement expected to be approved during the second day of the Group of Seven summit, the leaders expressed their deep dissatisfaction with the pace of refugee resettlement and other non-military aspects of the 1995 Dayton Peace Accords.
"We are prepared to continue to help the states of this region, but our continued commitment is not unconditional," the statement said.
It singled out Croatia and Serbia for special criticism, faulting them for failing to demonstrate "a stronger commitment to the peace process."

The statement sidestepped whether the NATO peace-keeping force in Bosnia would be withdrawn as scheduled in June 1998, saying: "We support the mission of the stabilisation force to help provide a secure environment by June 1998."
The United States plans to withdraw its 8,500 troops from the 31,000-strong force as scheduled.

European leaders at the G7 summit on Friday night expressed concern to President Bill Clinton about the withdrawal plans, but he refused to budge. The Europeans fear a U.S. withdrawal will lead the force to collapse and allow war to start again.
White House spokesman Mike McCurry said Clinton reaffirmed to the other leaders public statements he has made reiterating the planned withdrawal date.

"As the president has indicated, there is a defined mission that expires June of 1998 and that's the timetable we're on," McCurry said. "And the president simultaneously said we ought to do everything we can and use every available day to deepen and nurture the prospects for peace there."
Clinton's statements have been seen in the United States as falling short of a cast-iron commitment that the troops will in fact leave on the target date.

The draft G-7 statement warned that parties to the U.S.-brokered Dayton accords who failed to carry out their obligations, especially on allowing refugees to return to their homes, "will lose access to economic assistance."

It also demanded that the Bosnian government and Bosnian Serb leaders accelerate the the development of democratic institutions, including permitting a free press, in the war-ravaged former Yugoslav region.

"We call upon the leaders of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (Serbia) to meet their responsibility and obligations to work for a democratic, stable and secure future for their citizens," the draft said.

Reiterating a long-held position, it said it wanted to see war criminals brought to justice before an international tribunal and warned the governments in the region that economic and other assistance is "dependent on compliance with these obligations."
